comments.commentBody: I am an avid tennis fan, and I was shocked by Mr. Moore's crude comments. Really? He is in charge of one of the finest combined men's and women's tournaments on the tour, yet he feels this way? He cannot stay in his position with that kind of appalling lack of judgment, apology notwithstanding. Statements have consequences.

The strange thing is that the article itself seems to prove he was right. Instead of attempting to establish that the women's game is currently on par with the men, it shows a photo of Chris and Martina from decades ago, as if to admit that the women are below par now, but defending on the grounds that men once were too. But the man wasn't talking about the past, only about the present. Can a reasoned argument be made that the women's game is as compelling as the men's right now? If so it certainly wasn't in this article.  And meanwhile, demanding equal pay the women do not demand to play matches of equal length, meaning the men can often deliver much more bang for the buck than the women.
Apologize? He was right.
That just shows your lack of ignorance about tennis. But, let's not digress from the debate here.
Who even cares about American men's tennis?  Everyone I know only watches women's tennis. This neanderthal should be fired for his sexist remarks!

Look: tennis is not a contact sport (although, even if it were, so what?) If women have a better game--if they've EVER had a better game--let them prove it. All purses, for male and female events, should be combined (the problem of disparate purses solved right there), and there should be no segregation of the genders. Let the best man or woman win. Until then, all this is politically correct bloviation and fulmination.

The only problem for women is that men would win a much larger portion of the combined purses and matches. If someone thinks this rank sexism, then get behind the movement to eliminate gender segregation. Put up or shut up.

Not following your logic there Marsha. Of course beginning players should earn less money than the stars. That's the way the system works. The issue is not that money is the central motive of owners and players. It is that, notwithstanding the protestations of letter writers in this forum, the men's game is objectively more popular than the women's game. I'm sorry, but facts are stubborn things.
Inexcusable comments from Moore.  Djokovic is certainly no "gentleman" either given such tone deaf remarks.  Sad all around.

Meliflaw:
Since when are grace, balance and intelligence particularly feminine qualities? Do you really think that the reason we like to watch Federer is that he is in effect a "girly" man? You sound as sexist as Moore.

"Lady players"?! Whatever his private opinions, why would Mr. Moore publicly proclaim such gratuitous nonsense? (More to the point, why is such a twit directing a major tournament?) And what does it say about tennis fans that Roger Federer, who is past his prime, is still such a favorite? Perhaps because we appreciate his "feminine" qualities of grace, balance and intelligence?

Obviously this guy should be fired. A tournament director should never say such things about his sport. I imagine that this will be arranged.

However, crudely he says it, there is a correct point underneath. There is women's soccer and women's basketball, whose athlete do not get even 10% of the men's sports. But they do not play in co-ed tournaments, where women can flat negotiate for equal everything.

I regret that other women's sports get such mammoth disrespect. They deserve better. However, in tennis, they get too much. Women's matches get less TV viewership, fewer on-court viewers and, at Grand Slam tournaments, provide less entertainment hours. Those are the currency of entertainment remuneration!

If tournaments were purely separate for tennis, as they are for other sports, women would be grossly underpaid in tennis too. I love to watch women's tennis -- I would rather they be overpaid than underpaid.

Give me a break.

First of all, Bob Gates is a lifelong Republican and terribly partisan, You get the impression that the only reason he stayed on under Obama was to dig up some dirt for his "memoir".

I liked Gates as a defense secretary, and gives great, insightful interviews, but he's not some objective observer by ant stretch.

And two, Lincoln also took positions contrary to his true beliefs for political purposes, he did it all the time. I don't know if he laughed about it, but he certainly didn't let his personal beliefs get in the way of what he thought was right for the country, or for himself if it came down to it.

Bob Gates wrote in his memoir that Clinton took positions contrary to her true beliefs for political purposes and even bragged about it in private. If anyone wants to believe that this isn't just another example, go right ahead. The most powerful lobby on the matter, the Chamber of Commerce, believes there is a 75% chance that TPP will pass in the lame-duck, conveniently obviating the need for Clinton to publicly support it.
God bless Obama

Wow, leave it to the good ol' U.S. of A., the number one country in the world that incarcerates it's people in record numbers, murders more innocent civilians by feral police forces, and disenfranchises millions of its citizens's to lecture another country about civil rights. Insecure Obama just couldn't handle the chance of being called weak by his Republican detractors. He had to poke his host in the eye to look tough. Why am I not surprised?

Djokovic said it right: Equal pay for Equal work period. I don't see anything wrong with that. The last time I remember, both men and women got paid by the amount of hours worked and not by who you are and what you are. This is in many ways an unjust use of gender discrimination as an excuse to justify the means.

Love watching the women play tennis. Serena's serve is a sight to behold.

Raymond Moore has been getting too much sun.....He needs a very long vacation...far, far, away.
He deserves every penny.

Joshua - I find that IN THIS PERIOD OF TIME I am most drawn to watching women's tennis- especially Serena Williams. She is the ONLY top ten American player on the field - MAN or WOMAN - as a matter of fact, she's number ONE. That's plenty to be fascinated by, and for Americans, plenty to be proud of. Frankly, I'm surprised that's not mentioned, or appreciated, more.
Moore should be fired. If he is not. there goes Indian Wells/Paribas.
Yes--that Bowie was way too big.
I noticed that too...David Bowie ws a slightly built guy. And he was actually very believable in Basquiat, as an older Andy Warhol.

I felt like I'd seen this episode a million times before what with the coke meltdown and hallucination of a dead guy as the BFF.

A shame Scorsese attached himself to this - a boring retread of so many of his favorite tropes. Jagger? Did Jagger actually observe anything interesting about the record business or was he above it all?

This show is all style and nothing else. And as we know, 70s style was gaudy, trashy, no substance. The show has no substance.

Lastly, the actor playing Bowie was far too big and heavy to play that part. David Bowie was always a lithe, thin elegant man and weighed even less during drug-fueled 70s. Does whoever is casting this terrible show care whether the actors cast as famous people are remotely credible? This episode reminded me of how great David Bowie himself was playing Warhol in Julian Schnabel's "Basquiat." Schnabel is a great filmmaker. Maybe HBO should give Schnabel a contract to develop a series.....

I liked seeing young Bowie. What a talent, and how sad that he's gone.

Also liked the Buddy Holly song/scene. Of course I'm old enough to enjoy classic rock and roll nostalgia.

Liked seeing Olivia Wilde though that merkin was on the gross side. But what a beauty.

Richie's fall has reached the point that I feel embarrassed for him.

Finally, really liked the character of Ernst; he was funny, well acted. Hope he haunts Richie some more.
I agee. I enjoyed her wit and insight. Any chance she will return to this post?

My question also. She originally bought into Phillip as a member of some US security bureau checking up on  the FBI but now she must realize that story is no longer even slightly plausible. Is she playing along because she now realizes what Phillip is capable of and fears for her own life or does she love him and is willing to forgive anything? And the big question--who does she think he is? Any comments?
The tattoo is simply F.U. spelled out. http://www.amc.com/shows/breaking-bad/talk/2010/05/the-cousins-interview

Not to be too pedantic but that would be F.Y.

(There's an FYI joke in here somewhere, but I can't seem to make it self deprecating... so )
Hmm.. maybe FYI would be F.Y. Interminably.
I don't suppose we're ever going to told just what obscene phrase is tattooed on that dude's eyelids.   (That would have spiced up this episode considerably.)

This is in many ways a bad show, but this was a very compelling episode.

The media was eager to elevate many people to heroes on 9/11 and some of that was truly deserved. But if someone formerly lauded as a '9/11 hero' is found to have been less than honest, I can easily believe the media (and much of the public) would respond by tearing that person apart. And their family. If that's where the show is going, that Bobby and family will never be forgiven and never recover from their '9/11 mythology story' - this story is more interesting - and surprising - than I gave it credit for.
It's just a way to get both of them out of town so they can come back and save everyone like Carol did when they were all in the boxcar. IMO.
CBS does have a news channel. The fact that it is on the internet and not cable will matter less and less over time. It's better than any of the cable "news" channels.
